snippet: The buildings in Bossangoa are charred and abandoned, with most of the population of 50,000 now in refugee camps, one for Muslims and another for Christians.
abstract: Burned out and desolate condition of Central African Republic's regional capital of Bossangoa exemplifies effect of sectarian violence on country's rural regions; residents of city, which once had population of 50,00, now occupy two sprawling camps--one for Muslims and one for Christians.
lead_paragraph: The buildings in Bossangoa are charred and abandoned, with most of the population of 50,000 now in refugee camps, one for Muslims and another for Christians.

headline.main: Central African Town Is Left Charred, Empty and Hopeless Amid Violence
headline.print_headline: Central African Town Is Left Charred, Empty and Hopeless Amid Violence
